Problem:
Consider a thermal conduction problem in a rod with varying material properties. The heat distribution u(x,t) is governed by the differential equation \\(u_t = (k(x) u_x)_x + f(x,t)\\), where \\(k(x)\\) is the thermal conductivity, which varies along the length of the rod, and \\(f(x,t)\\) represents a heat source term. The transformation defined is \\(v(x,t) = \\int_0^t u(x,\\tau) d\\tau\\), to study accumulated heat over time.

If at a certain time \\(t_1\\), an additional cooling effect modeled by \\(g(x,t) = c \\cdot u(x,t)\\), where c is a constant, is introduced, will the function \\(v(x,T)\\) for \\(T > t_1\\) depend solely on \\(k(x)\\) and independent of \\(f(x,t)\\) or \\(g(x,t)\\)?
Explanation: Introducing the cooling effect \\(g(x,t)\\) as an intervention modifies the heat distribution \\(u(x,t)\\), affecting both the instantaneous and accumulated heat profiles (\(v(x,T)\\)). Both \\(f(x,t)\\) and \\(g(x,t)\\) thereby influence the final state of \\(v(x,T)\\), in addition to the conductivity \\(k(x)\\).
